prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

spanGrp.span: Let’s say, the visit of condolence here with us – may God never bring it (upon us)! When a person dies, when somebody dies, let’s say, after he has died, they wash him.

They take him away and then make condolence visits for him, for three days; for three days his family (does it). In former times it was even longer, but nowadays the more time had passed, the shorter it has become.
In former times, people used to keep it for weeks, for ten days. Nowadays not even the family of the house (of the deceased) would do it (that long).
They do no longer make food at home. But don’t you actually owe it to the people? They are people who do it for other people, so they are in debt to them.
The people keep doing it for them every evening; they bring them dinner or lunch or breakfast for a week.
The people; everyone keeps taking a turn and says, “Today is my turn.” They either make minced meat or stew or (bring) something ready-made; or he makes a thingy.
He keeps making it until, I mean, everyone does his thing, I mean, this is (a kind of) debt.
Because the deceased has also made it before. I mean, therefore one says, “Everything (in life) is loan and debt, even the tears.” This is what the Arabs say.
After the condolence visits are over they say, “Brother, on a Friday evening we want to make a mawlūd feast.”
The Arabs do (this) here, I mean they set the time when it is Friday evening, regardless whether it is after five days or after six days. They do the mawlūd feast (always) on Friday evening.
Then they also make the halvah; they make it together with the mawlūd feast and distribute it.
The food at the mawlūd does not come from people; (providing) the food at the mawlūd belongs to the family of the deceased.
And then they also give money. Let’s say, if he did not pray or if he did not pay his alms tax, his family will give it (now).

They say, “Brother, I (heard before) that the deceased has previously stipulated, he has devised: ‘Give five hundred million, give a milliard in return for my alms tax.’” Then his family gives it in return of his alms tax.
And then they also bring, let’s say, they will make his halvah; but some people there are people who just buy it ready-made.
They bring it in tins and say, “This is our halvah!” They bring the ready-to-serve halvah and put it on the tray.
They take it out and fill the tray, they put it on a piece of bread – either bread from the bakery or home-made bread – and then they distribute it.
And some of them bring a sack of flour, from a factory, a tin of ghee, and a sack of sugar on large metal bowls.
They pour the whole tin of ghee, let’s say, for example, onto two bowls. They pour out the tin of ghee, half of it here and half of it here and by doing so it becomes fatty.
And they put flour on it and then they also put it on the stove and then they keep slightly stirring it.
Let’s say, the women stir it until the flour becomes roasted a little bit. Then they mix it in another place, they mix it with sugar and
With a bucket full of sugar and with water; then they again stir it slowly slowly until it is done, until it thickens.

Then they take it out, put it aside and leave it to cool. They put, they put cereals on it, black cumin seeds; they bring almonds and some of them bring walnuts. It depends on their ability, I mean, who wants puts whatever he has on it.
However, without pistachios it does not work; and it is also impossible on cheese. That would be a shame! But whatever they find, they put on it; they put on it what they can find.

Afterwards they start to distribute it among each other and according to the tradition (it is said,) “Walk barefoot so that your father can see you!” I mean there are tales about (the saying,) “Walk barefoot, go!” This is what is said to the daughter of to the lady of the house.

For example, when my father died I am talking about my father’s death. Didn’t we also make halvah? It was said (to me), “Go barefoot, walk barefoot, without shoes as a sign for your father so that he will see you.”
(I said,) “My father is dead and where can he see me?” – “You should distribute it!” I mean, the daughter must distribute (the halvah) in order that no other would distribute it.

When she has distributed it, it is in order that no one could take the good deed from it. I will forgive my father’s (mistakes), but let’s say, whan a woman from the neighbourhood has distributed it for my father, she might have got tired and so she would perhaps not forgive my father.
It is said, “Let his daughter (do it), so she would forgive him.” After we have distributed my father’s halvah, when we have distributed it, we talked about my father and we did the mawlūd feast.

We invited everyone who had come to us for the visit of condolence. We invited him to our place according to the tradition. That day, (for instance), you, the master, did you come or did you not come for my father’s (condolence)?
You came and you said (lit. did) to us, “Sincere condolences!” I mean, you came and expressed your condolences to us, you came to Akçakale.
Then I call you on the telefon and I say, “Master!” I mean, either me or the children at home say, “Master, come, you are invited! Today is the mawlūd feast at our place.”
Whoever has come and has expressed his condonlences to them in Urfa, they would send after him and he would come to them to the mawlūd feast.
As for the halvah, the flour halvah is made like that, as I said. And let’s say, the thingy, people nowadays go and bring ready-made halvah.
The more time passes, the more civilised people and everything becomes, the amount (of halvah) is just half a kilo, just a little bit (in containers) with lids.
Like this, the ready-made halvah with a lid on it. It has a cover on it and is only this much! Let’s say, it is covered and this is a sign of politeness.
They are distributing it like this in the villages. They put a piece of pita bread or a loaf of bread on it.
From the loaf of bread it gets thingy I mean, everyday they are coming up with something. This is (what I can tell you) about the halvah of the deceased. God forbid!
